docs.text: Configuration This page describes the possible ways of configuration. Configuration File The default way of configuration is using the configuration file usually located in /etc/threatstate/threatstate.conf You can also specify different location with the command line option -f | --file . Example: threatstate -f myconfig.conf start Environment Variables Another way of configuration (Docker friendly) is using the environment variables. The environment variables take precedence over the configuration file. Example: THREATSTATE_PORT=4444 threatstate start Command Line Options Last, but currently rather limited way of configuration is using the command line options. Command line options take precedence over the environment variables. Example: threatstate start --port 4444 Complete Configuration Reference Configuration File Directive Environment Variable Type Default Value threatstate.debug THREATSTATE_DEBUG boolean false threatstate.host THREATSTATE_HOST string 0.0.0.0 threatstate.port THREATSTATE_PORT integer 8000 threatstate.base_url THREATSTATE_BASE_URL string http://localhost threatstate.security THREATSTATE_SECURITY boolean true threatstate.workers THREATSTATE_WORKERS integer 1 threatstate.sentry_dsn THREATSTATE_SENTRY_DSN string threatstate.logging.level THREATSTATE_LOGGING_LEVEL string WARNING threatstate.logging.dir THREATSTATE_LOGGING_DIR string /var/log/threatstate database.host THREATSTATE_DATABASE_HOST string localhost database.port THREATSTATE_DATABASE_PORT integer 27017 database.username THREATSTATE_DATABASE_USERNAME string threatstate database.password THREATSTATE_DATABASE_PASSWORD string password database.name THREATSTATE_DATABASE_NAME string threatstate

docs.text: Usage Installation This chapter describes various ways of installation. Installation from PyPI Install the package from PyPI repository: pip install threatstate Running the setup command will: create system user threatstate create default configuration at /etc/threatstate/threatstate.conf create default logging directory /var/log/threatstate sudo threatstate setup Installation from DockerHub This is described in it's own chapter "Docker". Running You may wish to run the following command to make sure everything is ready. sudo -u threatstate threastate check To start the application, simply run: sudo -u threatstate threatstate start

docs.text: Security You may choose to enable or disable security in the configuration. Enabled security enforces users to authenticate using Basic HTTP Authentication with every request. With enabled security it is also possible to add, edit or delete additional users. By default only superuser has this permission. The superuser name is threatstate and has a default password threatstate . The superuser can grant three types of privileges to the users: - READ (allows searching) - WRITE (allows inserting data) - MANAGE_USERS
